author: By Alex Lemonides
title: While life expectancy is rebounding in parts of the world, white deaths drive a further U.S. drop.
description: Life expectancy in the United States continued to drop in 2021, while rebounding from the pandemic in many other high-income countries, according to a new preliminary analysis that found the U.S. decline was driven largely by deaths among white Americans.
content: Life expectancy in the United States continued to drop in 2021, while rebounding from the pandemic in many other high-income countries, according to a new preliminary analysis that found the U.S. decline was driven largely by deaths among white Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Will a Ban on Foreign Real Estate Buyers Lower House Prices?
description: Among the many budget measures to make housing more affordable is a two-year ban on sales to foreign buyers. But details are scarce.
content: Soaring real estate prices, the second most popular topic of conversation among Canadians after the weather, loomed large in the federal budget presented to Parliament on Thursday by Chrystia Freeland, the finance minister and deputy prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Ruiz
title: Ayodele Casel Is on Tap for ‘Funny Girl’
description: The barrier-breaking master tap dancer is now taking the art form to Broadway, in a highly anticipated revival.
content: When chorus auditions began last December for the buzzy revival of “Funny Girl” on Broadway, many hopefuls struggled with the tap dance combination. Some, recalled a choreographer, stopped midway through, made prayer hands of gratitude and exited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Latest E.U. Sanctions Get Personal With Putin’s Daughters and Confidants
description: The targets included one of the most trusted technocrats in Mr. Putin’s economic policy team and the head of a construction empire who used to practice judo with the Russian leader.
content: A number of high-profile names were added Friday to the European Union’s list of sanctioned individuals as part of the bloc’s fifth package of measures against Russia, none more personal for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia than his own daughters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: How to Improve Heart Health After Covid
description: Evidence suggests that Covid survivors have substantially higher chances of developing cardiovascular disease. But experts say there are effective ways to minimize the risk.
content: Before Jennifer Fagan got Covid-19 in March 2020, she considered herself somewhat of a fitness enthusiast. She used to go running two or three times a week and took a hot yoga class almost every other day. But several weeks after she recovered from the initial stages of the illness, she still felt excruciating pain in her chest and got winded all the time. By June, she started having heart palpitations. “I told my doctor that I felt like I was in the body of a 70 or 80 year old,” Ms. Fagan recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Bruenig
title: The Case for Paying Parents Who Care for Their Own Kids
description: Is being in the formal workplace necessarily a sign of progress?
content: In some European countries, parents can choose between sending their children to heavily subsidized day care or receiving a stipend from the government to take care of them at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: In the Rush to Return to ‘Normal,’ What Happens to the Vulnerable?
description: We need a new normal.
content: “Covid-19 need no longer control our lives,” President Biden announced in the State of the Union address, speaking to a room of unmasked though back-room-tested members of Congress. He then offered, magnanimously: “If you’re immunocompromised or have some other vulnerability, we have treatments and free high-quality masks. We’re leaving no one behind or ignoring anyone’s needs as we move forward.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Delia Ephron Writes Her Way Through Cancer to a Happy Ending
description: Her new book is a medical thriller, a cancer memoir, a love story and a hero’s journey — except there were two heroes: Ephron and her husband, who walked with her.
content: The story behind Delia Ephron’s latest book, “Left on Tenth: A Second Chance at Life,” began sweetly, like the romantic comedies Ephron wrote with her sister, Nora Ephron, the beloved author, director and screenwriter of “You’ve Got Mail” and “Sleepless in Seattle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Football Asks Me to Make Moral Compromises. I Love It Anyway.
description: I’m not proud of myself, but nothing can keep me from this game.
content: American football is, to me, the most beautiful sport on earth. Every play is a high-level chess maneuver, performed by some of the most physically adept people alive. The intricacies of the game, the decision making, the coordinated dance of it all: it’s truly gorgeous. And at the professional level, football almost hums with the sound of its own excitement. There are moments in the midst of a great game when I think I’m lucky even to be able to watch it. It’s no wonder to me that football is the most popular spectator sport in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Didier Fassin
title: Emmanuel Macron Is Playing a Dangerous Game
description: How Emmanuel Macron absorbed the political views of his opponents
content: In 2017, Emmanuel Macron was “a meteor born under a lucky star.” A former banker without experience in elective office, he benefited during his first presidential campaign from President François Hollande choosing not to seek re-election, while the conservative candidate and front-runner, François Fillon, faced an embezzlement charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: New Rites of Spring
description: While we engage in the usual rituals of the changing season, we’re growing accustomed to spring cleaning our minds as well.
content: It’s breeding season for birds in my neck of the woods. I’m keeping an ear out for the mourning doves and pigeons, their magic-hour call-and-response. “The birds’ antics are an invocation to tune in — and to bear witness,” writes Margaret Roach, our gardening columnist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can Liberalism Thrive Without a Wolf at the Door?
description: The Ukraine War could inspire a reassessment of what liberalism should seek to be.
content: The idea that Vladimir Putin’s war against Ukraine would be a restorative tonic for Western liberalism, touted hopefully in the first few weeks of war, has taken sharp blows in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: In This Michigan County, Pandemic Stimulus Funds Are Remaking Public Health Programs
description: Many cities and counties say that shoring up local public health systems is crucial to recovering from the pandemic and addressing entrenched health disparities.
content: LANSING, Mich. — In an underserved neighborhood of Michigan’s capital city, a health clinic is being built with nearly $900,000 in federal pandemic relief funds, a project that could transform the community’s access to care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: When a Supreme Court Justice Probably Endorsed Perjury
description: Taking a close look at John Marshall and the Marbury v. Madison case.
content: My Friday column was on the history and origins (mostly origins) of judicial review in the United States. For research, I read a brief but comprehensive book on Marbury v. Madison and the 18th-century context for the emergence of judicial review in the early American republic. I also read the relevant chapters of two recent biographies of Chief Justice John Marshall: “John Marshall: The Man Who Made the Supreme Court” by Richard Brookhiser and “Without Precedent: Chief Justice John Marshall and His Times” by Joel Richard Paul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Michael D. Shear and Eileen Sullivan
title: Disagreement and Delay: How Infighting Over the Border Divided the White House
description: The Biden administration has furiously debated how — and whether — to unravel Trump-era immigration policies.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden was livid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aileen Kwun
title: One Garment’s Journey Through History
description: The evolution of the Korean hanbok is a lens into the history of the country, which is now being traced in the series “Pachinko.”
content: With spare, elongated lines and broad shapes that bloom into a voluminous silhouette, the traditional Korean hanbok, made to accommodate movement, is as beautiful as it is functional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Kim and Pete, or Vladimir and Volodymyr?
description: Can America stay focused on Russia’s evil in Ukraine?
content: WASHINGTON — Please, Kim Kardashian, don’t elope with Pete Davidson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Amoeba Feature
description: Sam Buchbinder breaks into Saturday with a solid challenge.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid, Sam Buchbinder’s Saturday debut, is a bit of a roller coaster! There are loads of excellent clues throughout, and I cruised up and down the west side with enthusiasm, noting appealing references all along the way. Then I hit a wall at the triple entries in the northeast corner and crept very cautiously through the rest of the puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Gardening, Nancy Drew for Adults and a Contract Killer
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Saudi Arabia will allow a million hajj pilgrims to visit Mecca, with Covid precautions.
description: Vaccinations and negative tests will be required for those who attend the annual ritual.
content: Saudi Arabia will allow one million foreign and domestic Muslims to travel to the holy city of Mecca this year for the annual hajj pilgrimage in July, the country’s Ministry of Hajj and Umrah announced Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson visits Kyiv, as Britain promises Ukraine armored vehicles and anti-ship weapons.
description: Mr. Johnson, an enthusiastic supporter of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, walked with him and a group of soldiers through the streets of the capital, Kyiv.
content: Making a surprise visit to Ukraine’s capital, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Saturday promised more military equipment and missiles to Ukraine, underscoring his country’s role as Europe’s most enthusiastic supporter of the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: With Macron and Le Pen Leading Election Field, a Fractured France Decides
description: In Dijon, magnificence and malaise sit side by side, in the image of a country divided before the presidential vote on Sunday.
content: DIJON, France — At Le Carillon, a convivial place for a coq au vin as France prepares to vote in a critical election, the heated political debates that always characterized past campaigns have fallen silent, as if the country were anesthetized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: ‘Transient Ischemic Attacks,’ Which Can Be Serious, May Need a New Name
description: Two neurologists argue that calling T.I.A.s what they are — minor strokes — could prompt patients to seek the help they need more quickly.
content: On a recent afternoon in Bastrop, Texas, Janet Splawn was walking her dog, Petunia, a Pomeranian-Chihuahua mix. She said something to her grandson, who lives with her and had accompanied her on the stroll. But he couldn’t follow; her speech had suddenly become incoherent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: After a Brief Scare, Mets Newcomers Lead Team to Victory
description: Tensions flared when Francisco Lindor was hit in the head with a pitch, but his new teammates, Max Scherzer and Starling Marte, led the Mets to victory.
content: WASHINGTON — The highest paid player in Major League Baseball took the mound here on Friday night and the surroundings were certainly familiar. Max Scherzer won the 2019 World Series and two of his three Cy Young Awards during his six and half year with the Washington Nationals, which made it odd for many in attendance to see him pitching for a visiting division rival and being honored with a tribute video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: I’m a Trans Woman. Bullies Don’t Surprise Me, but Allies Still Do.
description: Hating trans folks makes strange bedfellows.
content: In late March, President Vladimir Putin of Russia compared his country’s reputational plight to that of J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series. In a speech railing against the West’s efforts to ostracize Russia, Mr. Putin groused about “cancel culture” run amok, pointing to what he called the cancellation of the author because she “did not please fans of so-called gender freedoms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson
title: Russia Shuffles Command in Ukraine as Thousands Flee the East
description: The Russian campaign will be consolidated under a veteran of the Syrian war, while Western nations pump additional arms into Ukraine.
content: Russia reorganized the command of its flagging offensive in Ukraine on Saturday, selecting for the mission a general accused of ordering strikes on civilian neighborhoods in Syria, as Western nations poured more weapons into the country in anticipation of a renewed Russian assault in the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: In Mariupol’s Drama Theater, a Cry for ‘Mama!’ That Offered Brief Relief
description: A family shares its story of surviving the Russian attack on a theater that officials in the besieged southern Ukrainian city believe killed about 300 people.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — The explosion — deafening, blinding — collapsed the walls around them, and “the moments afterwards felt like an eternity, waiting to hear my child’s scream so I would know she was alive,” Viktoria Dubovitskaya said. “Maybe she will be without legs or arms, but just let her be alive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Women in Poland volunteer as drivers to offer safe transit to Ukraine’s refugees.
description: With women and children at high risk of exploitation, a volunteer collective called Women Take the Wheel is helping them make the journey.
content: Since Russia invaded Ukraine in late February, women around Poland have been making trips to the Polish-Ukrainian border to offer rides to the multitudes of refugees seeking safe passage out of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: I Got a Discount on My Rent-Stabilized Apartment. How Much Can the Rent Go Up Now?
description: As leases expire amid a hot rental market, tenants are reporting huge rent hikes. Here’s how to determine what you should be paying.
content: Q: A year ago, I moved into an apartment in a Brooklyn building for $3,800 a month. The lease I signed stated that base rent was $4,800, but I was being given a concession. Worried that rents might rise, I negotiated a rider limiting my rent increase to $200, and when my lease ended, my landlord offered me a new one for $4,000 a month. But after I did some research, I learned that the apartment is actually rent stabilized, so rent increases should be limited to the amount set by the city. But the landlord says that my base rent is $4,800, describing my lower payment as a concession. Is this correct or can I challenge it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Putin’s War in Ukraine Shatters an Illusion in Russia
description: Russians long lived with an understanding: Stay away from politics, and live your life as you choose. The war in Ukraine wrecked that idea.
content: The last time I was in Russia, the summer of 2015, I came face to face with a contradiction. What if a place was unfree, but also happy? How long could it stay that way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Feeding my desperate need to make words, one point at a time.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Spurred by Putin, Russians Turn on One Another Over the War
description: Citizens are denouncing one another, illustrating how the war is feeding paranoia and polarization in Russian society.
content: Marina Dubrova, an English teacher on the Russian island of Sakhalin in the Pacific, showed an uplifting YouTube video to her eighth-grade class last month in which children, in Russian and Ukrainian, sing about a “world without war.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Wave of Terrorism in Israel Defies a Simple Narrative
description: Four recent deadly attacks have highlighted Palestinian anger over vanishing prospects of a Palestinian state, but the assailants’ diverse backgrounds have left many questions unanswered.
content: TEL AVIV — The current surge in terrorist attacks in Israel has been framed by Palestinian parties and militant groups as a logical consequence of the entrenchment of Israel’s 55-year occupation of the West Bank, of Israel’s control over sensitive religious sites in Jerusalem, and of the dwindling commitment from some key Arab leaders to the creation of a Palestinian state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Terrible Tilly, Oregon’s Legendary Lighthouse, Is for Sale
description: The current owner of the lighthouse, built in 1881, has used it for decades to store cremated remains. Its new owners will decide its next chapter.
content: From a distance, the Tillamook Rock Lighthouse looks like a real-estate investor’s dream. There are views of Oregon’s coast from the tower, perched on a rugged island a mile offshore. Most days, the solitude is broken only by the sound of crashing waves, and the seclusion by nesting birds and sea lions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Arthur D. Riggs, 82, Dies; Led Team That Invented Artificial Insulin
description: His research into recombinant DNA provided a foundation for the biotech revolution, leading to a long list of lifesaving treatments.
content: Arthur D. Riggs, a biochemist whose pioneering research into the mechanisms of human DNA led him to a series of breakthrough advances, including the invention of artificial insulin and monoclonal antibodies, died on March 23 in Duarte, Calif. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Teenager Charged in Fatal Shooting of 16-Year-Old Girl in the Bronx
description: Jeremiah Ryan, 17, was charged with murder in the killing of Angellyh Yambo, who was shot as she walked home from school on Friday.
content: The police said that they had arrested a suspect in the fatal shooting of a teenager who was killed near her high school in the Bronx on Friday, the latest shooting in a monthslong string that has left New York City shaken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Eleanor Munro, Who Profiled Women Artists, Is Dead at 94
description: Her 1979 book featured interviews with dozens of artists, but she also wrote on other subjects — pilgrimages, for instance.
content: Eleanor Munro, who in an illuminating 1979 book profiled and interviewed dozens of women artists, probing for common threads in their works and their experiences trying to pursue the creative life in a society and art world that limited opportunities for them, died on April 1 at an assisted living center in Rye, N.H. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Giancarlo Stanton Continues to Mash Against Red Sox
description: Stanton has homered in six straight games against Boston. The Mets, meanwhile, are 3-0 thanks to Pete Alonso’s grand slam.
content: Giancarlo Stanton became the first player to homer against Boston in six straight games, hitting a tiebreaking, two-run drive in the sixth inning that gave the Yankees a 4-2 win over the Red Sox on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Officials Failed to Provide Accounting of Foreign Gifts
description: The State Department could not compile a list of gifts for 2020, making it difficult to determine whether officials did anything improper.
content: The Trump administration left office without providing the State Department with an accounting of the gifts former President Donald J. Trump, former Vice President Mike Pence and other White House officials received from foreign governments in 2020, the department disclosed late Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Alvin Bragg Says He’s Not a Politician. Is That the Root of His Trouble?
description: The Manhattan district attorney has had an uncommonly tumultuous first three months on the job, drawing criticism from all over the political spectrum.
content: In his first three months as the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg had an unusual number of bad days. Feb. 23 was among the worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: These Birds Form a Trio, but Probably Not a Throuple
description: Some pairs of cranes in India, known for their monogamous devotion, seem to bring in a third bird to act like a kind of avian au pair.
content: Cranes have a reputation as romantics. The birds live in faithful pairs, dancing and defending their territory together. When intruders approach, the birds lift their beaks and emit a loud song with one voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Popescu
title: Russell Westbrook’s Complicated Homecoming
description: The N.B.A. star and native Angeleno is thriving back in the city where he grew up. Just don’t ask a Lakers fan.
content: LAWNDALE, Calif. — “Go home,” Russell Westbrook yelled at a heckler seated behind the players’ bench. “Go home,” he repeated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Emissions From Tropical Megacities Could Usher in ‘New Era of Air Pollution’
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 9, 2022.
content: “Our analysis suggests we’re entering a new era of air pollution in these cities, with some experiencing rates of degradation in a year that other cities experience in a decade.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Power Returning to Puerto Rico, but Frustrations Remain
description: Although much of the island saw electricity restored on Saturday, more than 200,000 residents were still waiting.
content: Power has been restored to 90 percent of Puerto Rico, according to the island’s power operator, though more than 200,000 residents remained without electricity on Saturday, three days after the outage began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Parliament Ousts Imran Khan as Prime Minister
description: The country will now face early elections after days of brinkmanship in which Mr. Khan tried to dissolve Parliament to head off the no-confidence vote.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Imran Khan, the former international cricket star turned politician who oversaw a new era of Pakistan’s foreign policy that distanced the country from the United States, was removed as prime minister early on Sunday after losing a no-confidence vote in Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Downes
title: Pandemic aid stalled in the Senate and Shanghai remained in lockdown: The week in Covid news.
description: The federal government has run out of money to cover coronavirus vaccines, testing and treatment for uninsured Americans, but Congress has yet to approve more pandemic response funding. A bill that would allocate $10 billion for those purposes stalled on Tuesday when Senate Republicans refused to advance it without a vote to keep in place pandemic-era border restrictions that President Biden has moved to lift.
content: The federal government has run out of money to cover coronavirus vaccines, testing and treatment for uninsured Americans, but Congress has yet to approve more pandemic response funding. A bill that would allocate $10 billion for those purposes stalled on Tuesday when Senate Republicans refused to advance it without a vote to keep in place pandemic-era border restrictions that President Biden has moved to lift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly DiNardo
title: Don’t Call it ‘Kamping’: K.O.A. Goes After the Luxury Market
description: The well-known network of budget-focused campgrounds has introduced a new brand to focus on glampers. The company’s head explains the move.
content: This summer, Kampgrounds of America celebrates its 60th anniversary. Since 1962, when two businessmen started charging travelers a small fee to set up camp along the Yellowstone River in Billings, Mont., the company’s canary-yellow signs with a red tepee have become ubiquitous along highways across the United States and Canada, advertising budget camping and cabin accommodations. Now the network of more than 500 campgrounds more commonly known as K.O.A. is expanding into glamping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: At the Masters, Tiger Woods Will Take Some Ice With That
description: Woods’s improbable quest for a sixth green jacket rested largely on his recuperation regimen, but the weekend appeared to prove its limitations.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods stood in the glorious sunlight of a Georgia spring one afternoon this past week, a lingering dose of warmth before the frigid, hellish hours ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Idaho Supreme Court Halts 6-Week Abortion Ban Based on Texas’ Law
description: The court says Idaho’s law cannot go into effect this month as scheduled while it reviews legal challenges. The ban prohibits abortions after fetal cardiac activity is detected.
content: The Idaho Supreme Court on Friday temporarily blocked a law modeled after one in Texas that relies on ordinary citizens to enforce a ban on abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy as a way of sidestepping challenges to its constitutionality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Japan dials up measures against Russia, aligning itself with the U.S. and Europe.
description: The country has announced a ban on Russian coal and restrictions on imports including timber, vodka and machinery. It is also expelling eight Russian diplomats.
content: Japan is stepping up its rhetoric and economic measures against Russia for its invasion of Ukraine, furthering Moscow’s economic isolation and joining the United States and European nations in calling for investigations into accusations of war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Quarterback Dwayne Haskins, 24, Dies After Being Hit by Truck
description: A Heisman Trophy finalist at Ohio State and backup with the Pittsburgh Steelers, Haskins died on Saturday after being struck on a Florida highway.
content: Dwayne Haskins, 24, the backup Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback and a former standout at Ohio State, died Saturday, Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin confirmed in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Former New Yorkers Are Networking Through WhatsApp
description: The chat groups in Los Angeles and Miami have become so popular that now there are waiting lists.
content: In January Ryan McGarry, an emergency room doctor, was skiing in Utah when he struck up a conversation with the man sitting next to him on a chairlift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why Condé Nast Staffers Are Unionizing: ‘Prestige Doesn’t Pay the Bills’
description: What does it mean when the labor movement is embraced by the so-called media elite?
content: On an August night in 1999, roughly 800 guests traveled by boat from Lower Manhattan to gather at the Statue of Liberty for an event to celebrate the debut of Talk magazine, the new venture from the celebrated editor Tina Brown. The party quickly took on a mythic distinction in the city’s social history as a fin de siècle assemblage of Those Who Mattered, when print media still had the cachet to make those determinations. Madonna was there — so, too, were Michael Eisner, Queen Latifah, Kate Moss, Tom Brokaw, Jerry Seinfeld and Manhattan’s most prominent publishing figures. The uninvited needed years to recover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Vivian Giang
title: ‘There Is No Reasonable Way for This to End’: Bill Browder on How to Stop the War
description: Mr. Browder, once a major investor in Russia, discusses what influences Vladimir Putin and whether punishing the oligarchs around him could help end his aggression in Ukraine.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Estrin
title: How Covid Changed the Clergy in New York
description: As the city’s houses of worship hold in-person services again, faith leaders reflect on what the pandemic has taught them.
content: During the deadliest months of the coronavirus pandemic, when many New Yorkers most needed their faith communities, houses of worship were either closed or operating with limits on attendance. The solace of grieving with family and friends, the comfort of the communal rituals of prayer and the joys of ceremonies celebrating births and weddings, were missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Ordering Seconds
description: A Sunday debut from David W. Tuffs puts a lot on our plate.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today we have one of those grids that’s completely befuddling until that mental connection happens — click! — that brings clarity and an appreciation for the clever mind that assembled the pattern. David W. Tuffs is to blame; the pattern's execution required sifting through endless lists of phrases, but he enjoyed doing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Eve Edelheit
title: Trying Everything, Even Lettuce, to Save Florida’s Beloved Manatees
description: Pollution has killed the sea grass that manatees feed on, and they are starving to death in large numbers. Extraordinary intervention may not be enough to protect them.
content: INDIAN RIVER LAGOON, Fla. — At first, the manatees stayed away from the romaine lettuce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Classic Games, Lingering Scars and the Finish Line in Sight
description: Manchester City and Liverpool meet Sunday in the first of a series of collisions that could decide as many as three trophies. Neither team can be sure of what comes after that.
content: MANCHESTER, England — Pep Guardiola lay on his bed in a Madrid hotel room, staring at the ceiling, contemplating his next move. He had already endured two sapping games, half a dozen choleric news conferences, more than a week of highly charged, thinly veiled animosity. He was exhausted and exasperated, and he was still only halfway through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Fire Chief Killed While Responding to Nebraska Wildfire
description: Chief Darren Krull of the Elwood Volunteer Fire Department died in a car crash during a fire that has scorched some 30,000 acres in two days.
content: A fire chief in Nebraska was killed while responding to a wildfire that has burned nearly 30,000 acres in the south-central part of the state, destroying farms and prompting evacuations, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: As Tiger Woods Falls Behind at the Masters, the Spotlight Shifts
description: Woods struggled with a 78 as the leader, Scottie Scheffler, held off a challenge from Cameron Smith to head into Sunday’s final round with a three-shot lead.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Saturday is called moving day at the Masters Tournament because that is when top-performing golfers try to leapfrog up the leaderboard to position themselves for a championship charge in Sunday’s final round.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Big Texas Party
description: A Big Texas Party
content: A Big Texas Party
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Death Cleaning’: A Reckoning With Clutter, Grief and Memories
description: These letters are among the more than 500 responses from readers to our request for personal stories about dealing with their own lifetime accumulation of possessions or that of a loved one.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 9, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 9, 2022.
content: An article on Page 7 this weekend about the director Lileana Blain-Cruz’s Broadway directing debut with “The Skin of Our Teeth,” in one instance, misstates her given name. It is Lileana, not Lily; she does not use the nickname Lily.
source.name: The New York Times
